ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: n/a
N/A
Virtual discussion, independent reading, essays with comments and revision

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned valuable writing techniques for my future courses at Yale.
How to analyze essays in depth and the important aspects of a good essay
This course focuses on writing various forms of nonfiction essays. It greatly improved my ability to craft a well-written piece.
I learned a lot about different essay styles and writing a personal essay.
My writing ultimately did improve in this course and I feel as though I know how to better draw ideas from good writing I read.
Learned how to pay greater attention to detail in my own writing and in other people's. Improved my own writing and got a bit more comfortable taking risks in my writing.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: In person discussion would have been more engaging.

Strengths: Small class size, amazing instructor, interesting and diverse readings, reasonably scheduled/well distributed writing load.
Weaknesses: Class discussions of readings were always well guided, but I occasionally was left wondering what exactly the takeaway was.

This course was extremely organized and covered many different essay topics. It was also very fast paced and I think the course could have benefitted from an extra revision for one or two of the essays instead of a fifth essay.

All in all, I enjoyed this course and it did push me to become a better writer. The grading standard is however pretty tough, and some days it was demoralizing to see essays I thought were constructed well returned back with a poor grade.

The biggest strength in this course is probably Professor Caplan. The coursework itself is pretty straightforward: do the readings and discuss the technique in class, so the the professor is crucial to making the class experience as good or bad as it can be. Discussions in this class did not lag (thanks to Prof. Caplan's questions), and we were able to constructively look at pieces written by both our classmates and in the syllabus. This was an enjoyable course to take. I can't think of any real weaknesses to this course. The grading was quick and fair, the comments were helpful, and the expectations were clearly communicated to us.

Strengths: The process of writing a pitch before a draft was so valuable and Professor Caplan's feedback was always super detailed and helpful. I appreciated that there was such large breadth in the essays we read in terms of content and length. My classmates were also a joy :)
Weaknesses: Wasn't a big fan of some of the essays we read, some because of content and others just because the writing was a tad bit boring in places. I also felt like discussions could be a bit slow or redundant sometimes, and I wish workshops were a little bit more critical (constructively, of course, but whenever I was being workshopped I didn't think it was the most helpful because people didn't comment that much on what they thought could have been done better). Lastly, for some class sessions I felt as though we focused too much on content and not enough on specific details of the writing that we could identify and apply in our own writing.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: n/a
N/A

Seminars and classes focused on reading and writing seem to transfer fairly well to Zoom -- I'm a first-year, so I'm sure there was some intangible part of the experience lost, but I don't know any better and was pretty satisfied.
I thought the Zoom seminars were extremely successful.
I thought the structure of the online seminar was great.
This course might be the perfect course during COVID-19. The discussion was well adapted to zoom, and nothing directly about the writing process was lost due to the online format.
I think having everyone be unmuted unless their environment was loud would have been nice because we might have been able to avoid the hand raising.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes if a student desires a foundation in writing for future english or humanities classes.
Yes! Super helpful writing course for underclassmen
I would absolutely recommend this course to another student.
If you're interested in personal nonfiction writing, yes. It's a fun course and seems to be used as a gateway to other writing intensive courses.
I would recommend this course to any student who likes writing personal essays.
Ultimately I would, but only if they are willing to commit to the hard workload of the course.

I would highly recommend this course to anyone wanting to learn how to write better. I loved my time in this course. If you take it with Professor Caplan, expect to be challenged and encouraged in your writing. I would not take this course if you're looking for a low-commitment course, but if you're willing to put in the effort to improve your skills, you'll love this course.

Yes! My writing improved, and I find myself reading many more creative nonfiction essays on my time. The reading load was manageable and having a draft/revision due almost every week was not as daunting as it might seem. Professor Caplan is easy to talk to and he always stayed after class just to chat or to answer questions. I loved the different themes we were tasked with writing about--they prompted me to think more deeply about my experiences/little details about the world I had thought about but brushed off.
